{{Infobox musical artist | name = Sugar Blue | image = SugarBlue1988.jpg | caption = Lucerna music hall, Prague, 26 October 1988 | image_size = | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = James Whiting | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1949|12|16|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Harlem]], [[New York City|New York]], [[United States]]{{cite web |url= http://www.nfo.net/calendar/dec16.htm|title= Calendar/December 16|author= |date= January 10, 2008|publisher= Nfo.net / Big Bands Database Plus |accessdate=January 19, 2010}} | death_date = | instrument = [[Harmonica]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Blues]]
[[Rock music|Rock]] | occupation = [[List of harmonicists|Harmonicist]], [[singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = Late 1960s-present | label = Various | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|http://www.sugar-blue.com/|Official website}} }} '''Sugar Blue''' (born '''James Whiting''', December 16, 1949, [[Harlem]], [[New York City|New York]], [[United States]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[Grammy Award]] winning [[blues]] [[musician]], who plays the [[harmonica]].{{cite web |url= http://skopemag.com/2008/03/19/sugar-blue-by-diana-olson-2|title= Sugar Blue|author= Diana Olson|date= March 19, 2008|work= |publisher= Skope Entertainment Inc.|accessdate=January 22, 2010}} He is probably best known for playing on [[The Rolling Stones]]' [[single (music)|single]], "[[Miss You (The Rolling Stones song)|Miss You]]". An article in the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' stated: "The sound of Sugar Blue's harmonica could pierce any night... it's the sound of a musician who transcends the supposed limitations of his instrument."{{cite web|url=http://www.sugar-blue.com/startpage.html |title=Sugar Blue, Blues, Harmonica |publisher=Sugar-blue.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}} ==Biography== In the mid 1970s, Blue played as a [[session musician]] on [[Johnny Shines]]' ''Too Wet to Plow'' (1975) and with [[Roosevelt Sykes]]. Whilst in the company of the latter, Blue met [[Louisiana Red]] and the twosome toured and recorded in 1978. Taking advice from [[Memphis Slim]], in the late 1970s Blue traveled to [[Paris]], [[France]]. This led to him playing on several The Rolling Stones tracks ("[[Some Girls (Rolling Stones song)|Some Girls]]", "[[Send It to Me]]" and the aforementioned "Miss You"). [[Trombone|Trombonist]] [[Mike Zwerin]] backed Blue on his [[solo (music)|solo]] debut [[album]], ''Crossroads'' (1979). Following the release of his ''From Chicago to Paris'' (1982), Blue joined [[Willie Dixon]]'s Chicago Blues All Stars.{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | page= 170 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} In 1984, Blue's track "Another Man Done Gone", appeared on the [[compilation album]], ''Blues Explosion''. It won a [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] in [[27th Annual Grammy Awards|1985]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Traditional Blues Album|Best Traditional Blues Album]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mojohand.com/bluesgrammywinners.htm |title=Blues Grammy award winners by year |publisher=Mojohand.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}} Blue appeared with [[Brownie McGhee]] in the [[film]], ''[[Angel Heart]]'' (1987). Blue's next album ''Blue Blazes'' was released in 1994. It was followed by ''In Your Eyes'' (1995), and ''Code Blue'' released in 2007. On January 26, 2010, Beeble Music released ''Threshold'', Blue's latest album.{{cite web|url=http://blues.about.com/b/2009/10/30/sugar-blue-cd-preview.htm |title=Sugar Blue CD Preview |publisher=Blues.about.com |date=2009-10-30 |accessdate=2014-01-29}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0f0;" ||'''Year''' ||'''Title''' ||'''Label''' ||'''Number''' ||'''Notes''' |- |1978||''Red, Funk and Blue''||Black Panther||BP1001|| Duo with Louisiana Red |- |1979||''King Bee''||JSP||||Duo with Louisiana Red |- |1980||''Crossroads''||Blue Silver||BS 3004||France, recorded 1979 |- |1982||''From Chicago to Paris''||Blue Silver||BS 3012/3332||France, recorded 1980 with Slim Pezin, Earl Howell |- |1984||''High Voltage Blues''||JSP||1081||with Louisiana Red |- |1991||''Absolutely Blue''||Seven Seas/[[King Records (Japan)|King]]||KICP 341||Japan, recorded 1982 |- |1994||''Blue Blazes''||[[Alligator Records|Alligator]]||4819|| |- |1995||''In Your Eyes''||[[Alligator Records|Alligator]]||4831|| |- |2006||''Right Now''||Kozel||||Switzerland, George Kay Band featuring Sugar Blue |- |2007||''Code Blue''||Beeble||801|| |- |2010||''Threshold''||Beeble||802|| |}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/sugar-blue-mn0000482856/discography |title=Sugar Blue | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1949-12-16 |accessdate=2014-01-29}}{{cite web|url=http://bidders.co.jp/aitem/101796027|title=Absolutely Blue|author= |date= |work= |publisher= Bidders.co.jp|accessdate=January 22, 2010}} ===Compilations and reissues=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0f0;" ||'''Year''' ||'''Title''' ||'''Label''' ||'''Number''' ||'''Notes''' |- |1979||''Stars Of The Streets''||Whale Productions / Egg Records (France)||Egg 900582 Compilation||Performances of several street musicians were recorded live outdoors in the streets and parks of New York City. Track 1 : "Pontiac Blues" by Sugar Blue |- |1980||''Jazz Gala '80''||Kingdom Jazz||Gate 7010||Recorded at the Palm Beach Casino, Cannes, France |- |1984||''Blues Explosion''||[[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]||80149||Grammy winner, recorded live at Montreux |- |1992||''From Paris to Chicago''||EPM Blues Collection||756||Reissue of ''Crossroads'' and ''From Chicago to Paris'' |- |1998||''The Blues Spectrum of Louisiana Red''||[[JSP Records|JSP]]||||UK recording |- |2007||''Another Man Done Gone''||WNTS/Believe Digital||MP3 download||Reissue of ''Crossroads'' and ''From Chicago to Paris'' |}{{cite web |url= http://jazzlabels.klacto.net/epm.html|title= EPM Records Checklist|author= G.Heinlein & François Ziegler|date= March 2004|work=|publisher=Jazzlabels.klacto.net|accessdate=January 22, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/blues-explosion-mw0000194031 |title=Blues Explosion - Various Artists | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}} ==See also== *[[List of harmonica blues musicians]] *[[List of Chicago blues musicians]] *[[List of contemporary blues musicians]] *[[List of harmonicists]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.sugar-blue.com/ Official website] *[http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=sOKZKESWys0C&pg=PA198&lpg=PA198&dq=%22SUGAR+BLUE%22.+%221955%22&source=bl&ots=JffXSobFSE&sig=HpNiWP2aE_B79oQeXQYdKjAp6FM&hl=en&ei=jEQQS6fGAZCr4QaB7b2IBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CB0Q6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=%22SUGAR%20BLUE%22.%20%221955%22&f=false Biography at Books.Google.co.uk] *[http://www.pbase.com/soulfulimpressions/sugar_blue Photographs at Pbase.com] {{Authority control|VIAF=60724219}} {{Persondata | NAME = Whiting, James | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = Sugar Blue | SHORT DESCRIPTION =[[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[musician]] and harmonica player | DATE OF BIRTH =December 16, 1949 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Harlem]], [[New York City|New York]], United States | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sugar Blue}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues harmonica players]] [[Category:Contemporary blues musicians]] [[Category:Grammy Award-winning artists]] [[Category:Harmonica blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from New York]] [[Category:Songwriters from New York]] [[Category:People from Harlem]]
